narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: mostly lecture with some combination of seminar style questions and presentations at the end

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: This course mostly focused bifurcations and coarse-graining, within the overall structure of understanding complex and dynamic systems. The course was structured around examples so we learned about various aspects of complex theory through things like SIS models, the Ising model, cell automata, etc. I developed better coding skills (in MATLAB), an understanding of the mathematical nature of complex behaviors, and insight into many real-world problems.
All about complex systems, bifuraction, python and matlab coding, fixed points, and how complex systems are everywhere!
I learned about different approaches to analyzing complex systems, such as: finding fixed points, analyzing their stability, coarse graining systems with many degrees of freedom, etc.

learned a lot of different models and techniques within complex systems theory. learned how to think about physical problems in terms of their differential equations. learned how to analyze the stability of the system and how it changes with respect to the parameters (bifurcations). great overview of different physical disciplines such as thermodynamics and mean field theory. learned some coding in MATLAB as well.
This is a survey class on various topics in complex systems theory. Topics include nonlinear dynamics and chaos, criticality, and cellular automata.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: This course had good material and the lectures were easy to follow. However, it could have benefited from more organization; there is little information on the Canvas page besides assignments and the expectation were unclear at times, particularly for the final project.

The material of this course is extremely interesting and I loved it even though it was pretty hard intellectually. The Professor is cute but could work on being a little less intimating because sometimes I was afraid to ask questions for fear of getting judged. However, he was ready to answer the questions when I did ask.

Jun is a fantastic lecturer and explains things very clearly. He goes a bit fast sometimes but overall pretty easy to follow. Also great selection of topics for the course. Problem sets were usually interesting subjects with relevance to what we learned in class.

Strengths: very wide range of topics covered. Examples are simple enough to gain some intuition on the topics without going into too much formal theory. If you every come across a problem in complex systems, you'll probably know where to look in the literature to find an answer.

Weakness: this breadth comes at the expense of depth. This class covers a lot of techniques, but don't expect it to prepare you to actually use them in a research setting without further reading.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The lectures in this class moved from in-person to online, and that went pretty smoothly. Overall, the class adjusted very well to virtual engagement and nothing really was missing.

It went pretty well COVID wise...I think what could be improved is less of a stress on how participation will affect your grade because during this already stressful and axious time, having to think about always being in class otherwise we will get docked way too many points, isn't the best. I still think there should be some importance put on attendance though because you really must be in class to understand it all.

Jun's slides were phenomenal, and his annotations during lecture helped to think through a lot of different concepts. Jun manages to keep lectures engaging despite everyone being online in different time zones. The only class I consistently tuned into.
The small class size were very good for the virtual format.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I would recommend this course if you're interested in learning about lots of examples of complex systems. If you're looking for very rigorous theory, this may be too much of a breadth course. Only take this course if you have a really solid background in differential equations, but if you do then this course will be rewarding and informative. You have the opportunity to develop your own final project which is unique and really can cover whatever you're interested in, which is nice.

Yes! I would definitely recommend doing this with friend and particularly one that could help you on coding. I would not have survived if I didn't reach out to the other students for coding help since I only had experience in coding from 205L.
Yes, this is a good survey course of complex systems.

I would recommend this course if you are interested in gaining a broad, surface level exposure to various complex systems. However, if you are looking for a more in depth and rigorous treatment of the material, this may not be for you.

Absolutely. Course covers an interesting variety of topics and gets you to think about physical problems in unique ways. Lectures are engaging, and the slides are very well organized and prepared. Jun explains things very clearly and precisely, and also has many interesting stories to tell. The only thing is that Jun tends to ask tough questions during class, but he really means the best for your learning and you get used to being called on. Maybe goes a little too fast sometimes but show me a math class that doesn't. Overall great class
